gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Continuously Updated Digital Elevation Model (CUDEM) - 1/9 Arc-Second Resolution Bathymetric-Topographic Tiles

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: DOC/NOAA/NESDIS/NCEI > National Centers for Environmental Information, NESDIS, NOAA, U.S. Department of Commerce

gmd:positionName.gco:CharacterString: Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences (CIRES) at the University of Colorado, Boulder

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences (CIRES) at the University of Colorado, Boulder

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences (CIRES)

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) is developing a suite of digital elevation models (DEMs) for the U.S. coast to support a variety of NOAA missions, including improved inundation modeling and mapping, habitat characterization, and visualization of Earth's surface. The DEMs are being developed according to a 0.25 degree tiling scheme. The spatial resolution of the tiles "telescopes" from the coastal zone to the deep ocean floor at 1/9, 1/3, and 3 arc-second grid resolution. Only the 1/9 arc-second DEM tiles integrate both bathymetric and topographic data; all other resolutions map bathymetry only. The tiling of the DEMs facilitates targeted, rapid updates as new coastal and marine elevation data are acquired and become available. Bathymetric and topographic data utilized for DEM creation originate from a variety of sources, including (but not limited to) the NOAA Office of Coast Survey, NOAA National Geodetic Survey, NOAA Office for Coastal Management, U.S. Geological Survey, and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. The DEMs are referenced vertically to the North American Vertical Datum of 1988. The vertical units of the DEMs are meters. The DEMs are referenced horizontally to the North American Datum of 1983. The horizontal units of the data are decimal degrees.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The information provided on this page seeks to define how the GCMD Keywords are structured, used and accessed. It also provides information on how users can participate in the further development of the keywords.

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: Not to be used for navigation. Although these data are of high quality and useful for planning and modeling purposes, they are not suitable for navigation. For navigation, please refer to the NOS nautical chart series.
Produced by the NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information. Not subject to copyright protection within the United States.

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Distribution liability: NOAA and NCEI make no warranty, expressed or implied, regarding these data, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty. NOAA and NCEI cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in these data. If appropriate, NCEI can only certify that the data it distributes are an authentic copy of the records that were accepted for inclusion in the NCEI archives.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: THREDDS Data Server containing the Continuously Updated Digital Elevation Model (CUDEM) Bathymetric-Topographic Tiles.
Create custom data files by choosing data area, product type, map projection, file format, datum, etc.

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: The horizontal accuracy of a DEM is dependent upon the accuracy of the source datasets used in its creation in conjunction with the spatial resolution of the DEM. The horizontal accuracy of the source data collected using modern surveying techniques and equipment (e.g. Global Navigation Satellite Systems) is assumed to be 1 meter or better. Data acquired before the advent and widespread adoption of modern surveying techniques are likely less accurate. No quantitative horizontal accuracy analyses have been performed on the DEM tiles.

The vertical accuracy of a DEM is dependent upon the accuracy of the source datasets used in its creation in conjunction with the spatial resolution of the DEM. The vertical accuracy of topographic data collected using modern surveying techniques and equipment (e.g. lidar) is assumed to be, at worst, better than 0.5 meters RMSE. The vertical accuracy of bathymetric data is dependent on a variety of factors, including acquisition sensor/platform, post-processing, environmental conditions and surveyed depth range. No quantitative vertical accuracy analyses have been performed. on the DEM tiles.

Every effort is made to obtain the best-available (e.g. most recent) source bathymetric and topographic information in an area prior to DEM creation. The tiling of the DEMs facilitates targeted, rapid updates as new coastal and marine elevation data are acquired and become available.

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: All data is reviewed and evaluated for internal and external consistency with adjacent data prior to DEM creation. Anomalies are removed through visual inspection and automated filtering.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Common horizontal reference frames and vertical datums are established among disparate data and data are converted to a common data format, ASCII xyz, prior to gridding/interpolating. A variety of software can be used for projection/datum transformations and format conversions, including (but not limited to) Geospatial Data Abstraction Library (GDAL) software utilities, VDatum, ArcGIS, LAStools, etc. Once consistency among the input source data is established, the DEM surface is created through gridding and interpolation. Elevations in grid-cells constrained by source measurements are assigned a value according to a weighted average of all samples located within the particular cell, while elevations in unconstrained grid-cells are estimated through interpolation. Please see the DEM technical reports for a more detailed explanation of specific processing steps.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: DOC/NOAA/NOS National Ocean Service, NOAA, U.S. Department of Commerce

gmd:other.gco:CharacterString: NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: NOAA created the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) by merging NOAA's National Climatic Data Center (NCDC), National Geophysical Data Center (NGDC), and National Oceanographic Data Center (NODC), including the National Coastal Data Development Center (NCDDC), per the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015, Public Law 113-235. NCEI launched publicly on April 22, 2015.
